"**Can 't Fight This Feeling**" is a [power ballad](/wiki/Power_ballad "Power
ballad")[2] performed by the American rock band [REO
Speedwagon](/wiki/REO_Speedwagon "REO Speedwagon"). The single remained at the
top of the [Billboard Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")
chart for three consecutive weeks from March 9 to March 23, 1985.[3]

The song first appeared on REO Speedwagon's 1984 album _[Wheels Are
Turnin'](/wiki/Wheels_Are_Turnin%27 "Wheels Are Turnin'")_. It was the group's
second number-one hit on the U.S. charts (the first being 1981's "[Keep on
Loving You](/wiki/Keep_on_Loving_You_\(song\) "Keep on Loving You \(song\)")",
also written by [Kevin Cronin](/wiki/Kevin_Cronin "Kevin Cronin")) and reached
number sixteen in the UK.[4] "Can't Fight This Feeling" has appeared on dozens
of 'various artists' [compilation albums](/wiki/Compilation_album "Compilation
album"), as well as several REO Speedwagon greatest hits albums.[5]

REO Speedwagon performed the song at the 1985 [Live Aid](/wiki/Live_Aid "Live
Aid") concert; they were introduced by [Chevy Chase](/wiki/Chevy_Chase "Chevy
Chase"), mentioning that the song was a number-one single at the moment in the
United States.

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Can%27t_Fight_This_Feeling&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Music video")]

Two different music videos exist for the song. One is a basic video, appearing
almost homemade, featuring the band in the studio. It begins with [Kevin
Cronin](/wiki/Kevin_Cronin "Kevin Cronin") playing the piano, attempting to
find the key in which he can best sing the song (starting off in G major, he
later decides he can sing it better in A). After Cronin exchanges some laughs
with his bandmates, the song officially begins; the video essentially consists
of the band members lip-synching to the original track of the song. It then
concludes with Cronin uttering the line, "That warmed the cockles of my
cockles!"[6] The other version of the video is much more "professional," and
makes various references to the life-cycle.[7] Both videos have been shown at
various times on VH1 Classic (now known as [MTV
Classic](/wiki/MTV_Classic_\(U.S._TV_network\) "MTV Classic \(U.S. TV
network\)")).

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Can%27t_Fight_This_Feeling&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

It was referred to in [The CW](/wiki/The_CW "The CW") show
_[Supernatural](/wiki/Supernatural_\(U.S._TV_series\) "Supernatural \(U.S. TV
series\)")_ , in season 2 episode 5, "Simon Said". [Jo
Harvelle](/wiki/Jo_Harvelle "Jo Harvelle") turns this song on for [Dean
Winchester](/wiki/Dean_Winchester "Dean Winchester") in [Harvelle's
Roadhouse](/wiki/Harvelle%27s_Roadhouse "Harvelle's Roadhouse"). Later, he
sings it in the car (claiming the song had stuck in his head to a very
confused [Sam Winchester](/wiki/Sam_Winchester "Sam Winchester")).[8] It was
also featured in the [South Park](/wiki/South_Park "South Park") episode [Miss
Teacher Bangs a Boy](/wiki/Miss_Teacher_Bangs_a_Boy "Miss Teacher Bangs a
Boy").

It was featured prominently in advertisements for the film, _[Horton Hears a
Who!](/wiki/Horton_Hears_a_Who!_\(film\) "Horton Hears a Who! \(film\)")_ ,
and sung by the major characters near the end of the film as the titular
character celebrates his vindication and his charges' salvation.[9] In 2016,
the song was used in the UK and US on ads for [Sheba cat
food](/wiki/Sheba_\(cat_food\) "Sheba \(cat food\)").
